Subject: Initiating a reaction in Batch Reactor
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=228646714; y=VPScDnGroxbMtVswC6pVTcpMVay6xhT06f8mP35NZ9_95PfAkCAYpavgNHc
X-Yahoo-Newman-Property: groups-system
X-eGroups-Approved-By: dggoodwin <dgoodwin@...> via web; 04 Aug 2005 17:31:13 -0000

Hi,

I need to know how to initiate a reaction in Cantera for a Batch 
Reactor.
If I set ambient temperature as the initial temperature, the 
reaction does not take off. I tried modelling the fuel as CH4:0.9, 
CH3:0.1, H:0.1 to begin a reaction. But I'm wondering if there's a 
better approach for this.

In the case of my interest, my initial composition consists of a 
mixture of air and fuel diluted by exhaust gases (an over 
simplified case of exhaust gas recirculation). From some 
calculations, I set the initial composition of gases. But since 
the mixture is very dilute, the reaction does not take off even 
with CH4:0.9, CH3:0.1, H:0.1 and hence I had to raise the initial 
temperature. I had to put a temperature as high as 1800 to start 
the reaction and to my surprise, that initial temperature value 
doesn't even show up on the plots! I tried changing the time scale 
to make sure that what I first saw was actually true.

I couldn't quite comprehend where I was going wrong.

Also, my next step would be to run a continuously stirred reactor 
model for recirculated flows. I'm wondering, if there's a way to 
send a temperature pulse for initiating reaction. There's a 
"Gaussian" function in a python example. But, it did not send a 
temperature pulse. Instead the ignitor was modelled as a reservoir 
of H atoms.

Thanks,

Bhupinder

--
Bhupinder Singh
Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
University of Florida
Gainesville
